I am still working with Buckland's NEAT for Windows code.  
I have successf=
ully muted a genome following his convention.  
Now I want to do the specia=
tion and breeding.  
As I understand the heiarchy, there will be a group of=
 species made up of a population of similar genomes.  
Each genome is defin=
ed by its genes (m_vecLinks) and neurons (m_vecNeurons) AND a history of in=
novations to the genome over successive generations (m_vecInnovs).  
Howeve=
r, in Buckland's code, it is unclear how the m_vecInnovs, m_NextNeuronID, a=
nd m_NextInnovationNum are tied to individual genomes.

//-----------------=
---------------------------------------------------
//  CInnovation class u=
sed to keep track of all innovations created 
//  during the populations ev=
olution
//-----------------------------------------------------------------=
---

Yet when the CInnovation constructor is called in the Cga constructor:=

//--------------------------------------------------------------------
// =
Cga this constructor creates a base genome from supplied values 
// and cre=
ates a population of 'size' similar (same topology, varying 
// weights) ge=
nomes
//-------------------------------------------------------------------=
-

It is called outside the for loop that creates the population of genomes=
.  
How then is m_pInnovation tied to a specific member of that population =
in a given species? m_pInnovation is a pointer to CInnovation.

Granted, ea=
ch population starts with the same genome topoplogy, but as members of the =
population are mutated or die out or new genomes are added to a species, ho=
w are their individual innovation histories kept? 

Thanks for any clarific=
ation.

Raymond
